title: RS20985
content: Procurement contracts for federal agencies involve various forest stewardship services, such as cutting trees and treating materials. Contracts are currently awarded to the lowest bidder, but Congress could consider other factors like local employment or past performance. Some suggest selling commercially valuable materials separately under a procurement contract, a practice known as log sales. The authorization for Forest Service timber sales also permits log sales, but this authority has not been extensively used. The advantages of traditional procurement contracting include simplicity, familiarity to agency personnel and contractors, and opportunities for congressional oversight. However, a major limitation is the potential for enormous costs. The Forest Service has identified 36 million federal acres of frequent-fire forest ecosystems and 39 million federal acres of other forest ecosystems at high risk of ecological damage from wildfires. Treating these 75 million acres could cost over $20 billion, with a total cost of around $70 billion for all 231 million federal acres. Proposed changes to traditional service procurement contracting for forest stewardship could hinder efforts to improve federal forest health. Using desired conditions instead of tasks could enhance forest stewardship by focusing on the remaining site conditions. Proposed changes to traditional service procurement contracting for forest stewardship could enhance forest stewardship by focusing on desired conditions rather than tasks. However, challenges such as the lack of standardized measures and the complexity of log sales need to be addressed for successful implementation. Combining various activities like salvage sales with mixed-species planting or prescribed burning after thinning is seen as necessary to improve federal forest health. The proposed approach involves trading goods (timber) for services in forest stewardship contracts. These goods-for-services contracts require timber purchasers to perform additional services, such as precommercial thinning or watershed restoration, in exchange for paying less for the harvested timber. Pilot tests were authorized in the FY1992 and FY1993 Interior Appropriations Acts, with a broader test established in 1998 and 28 stewardship end result contracting demonstration projects authorized in the FY1999 Interior Appropriations Act. Following the authorization of 28 projects in the FY2001 and FY2002 Interior Appropriations Acts, goods-for-services stewardship contracting was considered in the 2002 Farm Bill. The House and Senate versions of H.R. 2646 differed on the authorization of goods-for-services contracting for the Forest Service, with the final bill (P.L. 107-171) not including any provision on this type of contracting. President Bush proposed goods-for-services stewardship contracting after the severe 2002 fire season as part of his Healthy Forests Initiative. The Senate debated stewardship contracting in the FY2003 Interior Appropriations Act. Section 323 of the FY2003 Interior Appropriations Act (P.L.108-7) amended provisions for stewardship end result contracting, extending the program to BLM lands and national forests through FY2013. It allowed the selection of a contracting officer without constraints and modified goals to remove "noncommercial" from cutting objectives. The approach also allowed agencies to impose non-timber harvesting requirements on purchasers, but did not specify commercial timber sales directly. The statute authorizes removing vegetation and applying the value of timber or other forest products to offset the cost of services received. Goods-for-services contracting can lead to greater efficiency and lower costs in forest stewardship activities by using the same equipment and personnel for multiple tasks. Proponents claim it is beneficial because it provides off-budget financing for forest stewardship. Goods-for-services contracting is a proposed approach for off-budget financing of forest stewardship, allowing federal agencies to purchase stewardship services with timber assets instead of appropriations. However, limitations include higher contracting costs due to combining multiple activities in one contract, leading to a cumbersome process and potentially higher overall costs. Critics suggest that simpler contracting procedures and longer-term authorizations are needed to fully realize the benefits of this approach. The provision for goods-for-services contracting provides longer-term authorization but may lack congressional oversight. Critics question the appropriateness of this approach, as it creates incentives for managers to increase timber sales to fund services. The goods-for-services contracting approach creates incentives for managers to support timber harvests to fund environmental restoration, including wildfire protection activities. Critics question the appropriateness and effectiveness of this long-term program. The effectiveness and efficiency of goods-for-services stewardship contracting have not been independently evaluated despite being seen as an important experimental opportunity to test alternative contracting arrangements under real-world conditions.
